stem: A 6-year-old child with a history of asthma is brought to the emergency department. The child is wheezing, has a respiratory rate of 36, and an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. The nurse is preparing to administer medications. Identify the actions the nurse should take and the actions the nurse should avoid.

itemContext.sbar: S: Alex Johnson, 6-year-old male, presented to the ED with increased wheezing and shortness of breath. History of asthma. B: Mother reports symptoms started this morning and have progressively worsened. A: Respiratory rate 36, oxygen saturation 88% on room air, audible wheezing. Alert and responsive but anxious. R: Preparing to administer medications as ordered.

rationale.correct: Administering a bronchodilator such as albuterol helps to open the airways and improve breathing. Administering oxygen helps to increase the oxygen saturation. Monitoring respiratory status helps to assess the effectiveness of the interventions. Elevating the head of the bed promotes optimal lung expansion.
rationale.incorrect: Administering a sedative can depress the respiratory drive and worsen the child's condition. Placing the child in a supine position can restrict lung expansion. Withholding fluids can lead to dehydration and thickened secretions. Waiting to administer medications can delay treatment and worsen the child's condition.
clinicalPearls: Asthma exacerbations in children require prompt treatment with bronchodilators and oxygen.
Regular assessment of respiratory status is crucial to monitor the effectiveness of interventions.
rationale.questionTrap: The question traps are related to actions that would be detrimental to a child experiencing an asthma exacerbation, such as administering sedatives or withholding fluids.

taskId.title: Asthma Exacerbation Management
taskId.description: Manage a child experiencing an asthma exacerbation.

outcomeOptions.text: Elevate the head of the bed
Place the child in a supine position
